entry.title: To built a strong understanding of how LLM and GenAi works and why it is important in todays world
entry.content:
Topics Covered

  • Famous LLMs: GPT, Mistral, LLaMA, Claude
  • Real-life use cases
  • How an LLM actually works
  • Why LLMs matter in 2025

 

What is an LLM?

LLM stands for Large Language Model.

It is a type of Artificial Intelligence designed to understand, generate, and interact using human language.

LLMs are trained on massive datasets such as books, websites, technical documentation, and Wikipedia.

 

Examples include ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, LLaMA, and Mistral.

 

Think of an LLM as a highly advanced auto-complete system ‚Äî not just for words, but for conversations, code, documents, and reasoning.

 

Why LLMs Matter in 2025

  • ‚ÄúLLMs are augmenting and, in some cases, replacing traditional rule-based software
  • They power chatbots, AI tutors, code assistants, and business analysis tools
  • They are easy to integrate into applications via APIs
  • The future of work is You + AI ‚Äî LLMs act as intelligent assistants

 

Famous LLMs

  • GPT (OpenAI): Strong reasoning, coding, and enterprise adoption
  • Claude (Anthropic): Safe, long-context, document-heavy workloads
  • LLaMA (Meta): Open-weight, customizable enterprise models
  • Mistral: Lightweight, fast, cost-efficient open models

 

Real-Life Use Cases

  • Customer support chatbots
  • Document summarization
  • Code generation and review
  • SAP process guidance and copilots
  • Knowledge search across enterprise documents

 

Start thinking of how you can build AI tools using LLMs, even if you're a beginner.

 

 

How Does an LLM Actually Work?

 Simple explanation:

  1. Tokenization: Breaks your text into smaller units (tokens)
  2. Embedding: Converts tokens into numbers (vectors)
  3. Transformer: Uses an attention mechanism to decide which words matter
  4. Prediction: Generates the next token (word/letter) based on training

‚ÄúAttention is all you need‚Äù

‚Äì the core of how LLMs work

 

‚ÄúAttention is all you need‚Äù ‚Äî the core idea behind modern LLMs

 

 

 


Step 1: Tokenization

Tokenization is the process of breaking input text into smaller units called tokens.
Depending on the tokenizer, these tokens may represent words, subwords, or characters.

Input:
"Create sales order for customer"

Example (subword-style tokens):
["Create", " sales", " order", " for", " customer"]

 These are not plain word splits.
Whitespace is preserved (for example, " sales" includes a leading space), which helps the model understand context and sentence structure more accurately.

This approach enables the model to:

  • Handle domain-specific terms (e.g., sales order, customer)
  • Support multi-language enterprise data
  • Gracefully manage unseen or rare words

You can visualize how tokenization works using OpenAI‚Äôs tokenizer tool:
üîó https://platform.openai.com/tokenizer

 

 

Step 2: Embeddings (Vector Representation)

After tokenization, each token is converted into a numerical vector, called an embedding.
An embedding is a list of numbers that represents the semantic meaning of a token in a high-dimensional space.

Important point (correctness):

  • One token ‚Üí one embedding vector
  • Typical vector sizes are 768, 1024, or higher, depending on the model
  • If a sentence has N tokens, the model produces N vectors

SAP Business Example

Input text:
"Create sales order for customer ABC"

Example tokenization (simplified):
["Create", " sales", " order", " for", " customer", " ABC"]

Each token is converted into a vector:

"Create"     ‚Üí [0.12, -0.55, 1.03, ...]" sales"     ‚Üí [0.45,  0.82, 0.66, ...]" order"     ‚Üí [0.78, -0.21, 0.14, ...]" customer"  ‚Üí [-0.34, 0.91, 0.02, ...]

Individually meaningless, but meaningful in relation to other vectors

  • Business intent
  • Context (action vs object)
  • Domain relevance (sales, order, customer)

Do All LLMs Generate the Same Embedding?

No ‚Äî embeddings are NOT universal.
The same word (e.g., Material, Vendor, Sales Order) will have different vectors depending on:

  1. The model
    GPT, BERT, LLaMA, etc., use different architectures and objectives.
  2. Training data
    A model trained on enterprise or ERP data understands SAP terms more precisely.
  3. Tokenizer strategy
    BPE, WordPiece, or SentencePiece can split SAP terms differently
    (e.g., SalesOrder vs Sales + Order).

Why Embeddings Matter in SAP Semantic Search

Traditional SAP search works like this:

  • Exact keyword match
  • Field-based filtering
  • Limited understanding of intent

Embeddings change this completely.

üîπ With embeddings, meaning is compared instead of text.

Example:

User searches:

"How to create a customer order?"

SAP documents may contain:

  • "Sales Order creation using VA01"
  • "Process flow for order-to-cash"

 Even though the words differ, embeddings place them close together in vector space, allowing the system to retrieve the right documents.

 

Step 3: Transformer (Self-Attention)

This is where the model understands context.
The Transformer uses a mechanism called self-attention, which allows it to look at all tokens in the sentence at the same time and determine:

  • Which tokens are most important
  • How tokens are related to each other
  • Where the model should focus more or less

Key correctness note:
Attention does not ‚Äúthink‚Äù sequentially like humans.
Instead, it assigns weights to relationships between tokens based on learned patterns.

Example (Conceptual)

Input sentence:
"Most famous product in France"

The model learns relationships such as:

  • ‚Äúproduct‚Äù ‚Üî ‚ÄúFrance‚Äù (geographic relevance)
  • ‚Äúfamous‚Äù increases importance by acting as a qualifier
  • Contextually important tokens receive higher attention weights

 As a result, the attention mechanism focuses more strongly on:

  • " product"
  • " France"

while giving less weight to supporting words like "most" or "in".

SAP Business Example

Input:
"Create sales order for customer ABC"

Through self-attention, the model learns:

  • ‚Äúsales order‚Äù is the core business object
  • ‚Äúcustomer ABC‚Äù provides critical context
  • ‚Äúcreate‚Äù indicates an action or intent

 This enables the model to distinguish between:

  • Sales Order creation
  • Customer master data
  • Order-to-Cash process

even though all words appear in the same sentence.

Intuitive Explanation (Human Analogy)

You can think of attention like this:

‚ÄúThe key concept here is a Sales Order,
the customer gives context,
and the verb tells me what action is required.‚Äù

The model doesn‚Äôt reason like a human, but self-attention mathematically achieves the same outcome by emphasizing the most relevant parts of the input.

Step 4: Prediction (Output Generation)

After processing the input through embeddings and transformer layers, the LLM produces a probability distribution over the next possible tokens.

At this stage, the model outputs logits/probabilities, which are then converted to text via decoding.
Instead, it predicts which token is most likely to come next, based on everything it has learned so far (prompt + prior tokens).

SAP Business Example

Input prompt:
"Create sales order in SAP"

The model internally computes probabilities such as:

  • " using" ‚Üí 42%
  • " for" ‚Üí 28%
  • " via" ‚Üí 15%
  • " transaction" ‚Üí 10%
  • " automatically" ‚Üí 5%

A decoding algorithm (e.g., greedy decoding, top-k, or nucleus sampling) selects the next token based on these probabilities.

Generated output (step by step):

  • "Create sales order in SAP using VA01"
  • "Create sales order in SAP using VA01 transaction"

This process repeats one token at a time until a stopping condition is reached.

What Influences the Prediction?

The final output depends on multiple factors:

  • Training data
    Determines how well the model understands SAP terminology and processes.
  • Prompt context
    Small prompt changes can significantly alter the output.
  • Temperature
    • Low temperature ‚Üí more deterministic, factual responses
    • High temperature ‚Üí more creative, diverse outputs
  • Maximum token limit
    Controls how long the response can be.

Correctness note:
The model always predicts one next token at a time, even when generating long paragraphs.

How This Works Conceptually (Linked to the Diagram)

  1. Prompt + previous tokens are fed into the LLM
  2. The model computes a probability distribution over the vocabulary
  3. A decoding strategy selects one token
  4. The selected token is appended to the output
  5. Steps 1‚Äì4 repeat until completion

 



 




1. Temperature

Temperature controls how random or deterministic the model‚Äôs output is.
It influences how the model samples from the probability distribution of the next token.

  • Low temperature (e.g., 0.2‚Äì0.3)
    • Output is highly deterministic
    • The model almost always selects the highest-probability token
    • Best for enterprise, SAP, and factual use cases
  • High temperature (e.g., 1.0 or above)
    • Output becomes more diverse and creative
    • The model samples from a broader range of tokens
    • Useful for brainstorming, ideation, or creative writing

 In simple terms:

Lower temperature = precision and consistency
Higher temperature = variety and creativity

SAP-Oriented Intuition

Prompt:
"Create sales order in SAP"

  • Low temperature:
    ‚Üí "Create sales order in SAP using VA01"
  • High temperature:
    ‚Üí "Create a sales order in SAP through standard order processing steps"

Same knowledge ‚Äî different expression style, controlled by temperature



2. Top-k Sampling

Top-k sampling limits the model‚Äôs choices to only the k most likely tokens.
Instead of considering the entire vocabulary, the model:

  • Selects the top k tokens with the highest probabilities
  • Discards all remaining tokens
  • Randomly samples only from this reduced set, weighted by their probabilities

Common values:

  • k = 20‚Äì50 for balanced outputs
  • Lower k ‚Üí more deterministic
  • Higher k ‚Üí more diversity

Simple Intuition

If the model predicts thousands of possible next tokens:

  • Top-k = 40
    ‚Üí Only the 40 most likely tokens are kept
    ‚Üí Everything else is ignored
    ‚Üí Sampling happens only within these 40 tokens

This prevents:

  • Rare, nonsensical words
  • Extremely low-probability noise

SAP Business Example

Prompt:
"Create sales order in SAP"

Next-token probabilities (simplified):

Token

Probability

using

0.45

for

0.25

via

0.15

automatically

0.08

process

0.03

‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶

With Top-k = 3:

  • Allowed tokens ‚Üí ["using", "for", "via"]
  • All other options are discarded
  • Final token is sampled only from these three

This ensures outputs remain relevant to SAP context.

 



3. Top-p Sampling (Nucleus Sampling)

üîπ Top-p sampling selects the smallest set of tokens whose cumulative probability exceeds a threshold p.
Instead of fixing the number of tokens (like Top-k), the model:

  • Sorts tokens by probability (highest ‚Üí lowest)
  • Keeps adding tokens until their total probability ‚â• p (e.g., 0.9)
  • Samples randomly only from this dynamic set
  • Discards all remaining tokens

Because the set size changes per step, Top-p is more adaptive than Top-k.

Why Top-p Is Different from Top-k

  • Top-k ‚Üí fixed number of tokens (rigid)
  • Top-p ‚Üí variable number of tokens (context-aware)

If the model is confident:

  • Few tokens may already reach p = 0.9

If the model is uncertain:

  • More tokens are included automatically

SAP Business Example

Prompt:
"Create sales order in SAP"

Next-token probabilities (simplified):

Token

Probability

Cumulative

using

0.45

0.45

for

0.25

0.70

via

0.15

0.85

automatically

0.08

0.93

process

0.04

0.97

With Top-p = 0.9:

  • Selected tokens ‚Üí ["using", "for", "via", "automatically"]
  • Sampling happens only within this nucleus

üìå This adapts naturally based on SAP context and wording.

When to Use Top-p (SAP Perspective)

Use Top-p when you want:

  • Stable, context-aware enterprise responses
  • Flexibility across different prompts
  • Fewer tuning headaches than Top-k

Common enterprise setting:

  • top_p = 0.9
  • temperature = 0.2‚Äì0.4


4. Min-p Sampling (Minimum Probability Cutoff)

Min-p sampling removes all tokens whose probability falls below a fixed threshold p.
Only tokens that individually meet the minimum probability requirement are allowed for sampling.

  • Tokens with probability < p are discarded
  • Sampling happens only among the remaining high-confidence tokens
  • Unlike Top-k or Top-p, the cutoff is based on absolute probability, not rank or cumulative mass

Example threshold:

  • min_p = 0.05 or 0.1

Simple Intuition

If the model predicts the next token with probabilities:

Token

Probability

using

0.45

for

0.25

via

0.15

automatically

0.08

process

0.04

‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶

With min-p = 0.1:

  • Allowed tokens ‚Üí ["using", "for", "via"]
  • Tokens like "automatically" and "process" are removed
  • Sampling occurs only among confident choices

SAP Business Example

Prompt:
"Create sales order in SAP"

Using Min-p ensures:

  • Rare or irrelevant words are filtered out
  • Outputs stay business-accurate
  • No low-confidence or nonsensical tokens appear in responses

Especially useful in:

  • SAP copilots
  • Transaction guidance
  • Compliance-sensitive outputs

When Min-p Is Useful (Enterprise Perspective)

Use Min-p when:

  • You need high precision
  • Hallucinations must be avoided
  • The domain vocabulary is well-defined (SAP, ERP, finance)

 

 

 

Recommended Enterprise Settings:

  • Temperature: 0.2 ‚Äì 0.4
  • Top-p: 0.9
  • Min-p: 0.05
  • Avoid very high temperature for business use

 

Key Takeaway

LLMs do not think like humans.

They predict the next most likely token ‚Äî repeatedly ‚Äî guided by probabilities and attention.

entry.title: Re: Error When Generating DOC via ‚ÄúRun Statutory Reports‚Äù...
entry.content:
Good day @Yaya_AB 

Thank you for your question

The fact that you performed the same process /Test in your test system without errors but the client gets the Generation failed error could be based on a few factors. I suggest you check if:

  • There are missing business catalog or lack of authorisation for report run objects on your client‚Äôs side. The reason is, the functionality depends on both tenant and user. Which often differs between Test and Prod. See KBA 3587016 for more insights.
  • The statutory reporting configuration in the prod tenant is complete. For example, reporting entity, assignments or your FEC setup might be inconsistent. See reference below for more details:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/33b132c0121c41f3b412258173d76b0d/358fb318c9cc4ceb8299135ec2c03a6f.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/33b132c0121c41f3b412258173d76b0d/e937bec0b2b94d628c71b7bb95b91aa5.html?locale=en-US

  • The error is generated because of data volume or your runtime issue which might lead to a backend error. See KBA 3575645 for some instances.
  • The run technically created something but the file it produced cannot be downloaded or is empty.

I suggest you capture the run log and the background job log first, then you validate statutory reporting setup and user catalogs in your client‚Äôs productive system.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Archiving Custom Database Tables in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
I assume you want to use the archiving framework provided by SAP.
First you should define whether you want to archive for volume management (without ILM) or rather data destruction (with ILM) based on retention period and if the released API covers your requirements. According to the documentation, both can be used for custom tables. Have you tried the example implementations?
Both variants eventually use the Archive Development Kit (ADK) API to store the archive file in the storage system - compressed as binary data. You cannot decide the format. You need ABAP Logic to deserialize the binary data. There is no option to store it in a human readable, structured format.
As far as I know, the REST API of DMS does not support reading stored files with offset (length). Therefore I would not recommend using it because ADK likes to read in small packages. For SAP Archiving objects, the storage system is now SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake Files (HDLF). Therefore I would recommend HDLF as the storage system for your custom archive objects.
In the volume management variant you need to implement a storage manager. This is the interface for ADK to the storage system. In your custom storage manager implementation you can call any storage system you like.
Unfortunately, we don't have an example implementation of a custom storage manager for HDLF but we are working on it. Basically you call the REST API of the storage system and send the archive file which is handed over by ADK to the storage manager.

entry.title: Re: Securing Enterprise AI on SAP BTP: Zero Trust Authentication with SAP AI Core
entry.content:
Yes.  From December 2024, creating new SAML trust configurations in SAP BTP cockpit is deprecated for user-interactive authentication (Cloud Foundry, customer-owned accounts). Existing SAML configurations continue to work for now, but SAP intends to remove SAML logins from BTP in the future via a dedicated release note. My understanding is that SAML can still be used behind IAS in proxy mode.

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003521979

entry.title: Clean Core maturity and the new Extensibility Levels
entry.content:
For years, the architectural conversation around SAP S/4HANA seemed trapped in a rigid side.
On one side, the purist vision moving all development to side-by-side extensibility on SAP BTP. On the other side, the operational reality, where complex transactional logic and proximity to data made decoupling code technically expensive and sometimes unfeasible..

However, we often lost in this conversation: Clean Core... what's side-by-side... what's On-stack
Not so far back in time, we followed the 3-Tier Development Model. This framework tried to organize development into three tiers (Tier 1 for Cloud, Tier 2 with Wrappers, Tier 3 for Legacy).

While useful, there's a new pragmatic second generation framework: the Clean Core Level Concept
This new maturity model increases the availability of APIs and reduces the forced need for wrappers, incorporating classic ABAP use cases safely. But how does this translate into the modern architecture of Levels A, B, C, and D?

Level A: The Gold Standard (On-stack & Side-by-side)
Level A doesn't force you off-stack. It represents extensions that rely exclusively on stable, public interfaces backed by stability. Is agnostic to the deployment environment:

Side-by-side Extensions: Decoupled extensions running on the Business Technology Platform. This ecosystem allows for SAP Build (low-code/pro-code), CAP (Java/Node.js), and ABAP Cloud (Steampunk) to create scalable apps and automations

On-stack Extensions: Created inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud (either as Key User Extensions or Developer Extensions). This validates that building tightly coupled logic within the S/4HANA it's ok, provided that released technologies like RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming) and CDS Views are used. So that by using of released APIs and strict syntax checks, you can build tightly coupled logic (essential for transactional integrity) without creating technical debt

Level B: The Pragmatism of "Classic APIs"
Unlike Level A, which relies on stability contracts, Level B uses Classic APIs and frameworks. While not strictly "Cloud" capable, these are nominated by SAP product experts as upgrade-stable.

You can identify these in the Cloudification Repository. Object frameworks such as SAPscript, and ALE/IDoc integrations fall into this category. This provides a critical "safe harbor," allowing to leverage proven legacy technologies without facing immediate refactoring pressure

Level C: Risk Management and Changelogs
When business reality demands the use of internal SAP objects for legacy scenarios, we enter Level C. Unlike the previous levels, there is an upgrade risk here. To mitigate it, SAP provides the Changelog for SAP Objects, a tool that allows you to identify incompatible changes early and plan proactive actions. Although not the preferred approach, it is a valid option if managed with wrappers to isolate the dependency.

Level D : The red line (Technical Debt)
Any extension that uses non-recommended techniques, such as direct modifications to the standard, direct writing to tables, or Implicit Enhancements, falls into this category. This represents the highest risk of technical debt and must be rigorously blocked using ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) checks. These patterns bypass standard logic and guarantee disruption during upgrades

Extensions objects are classified as unfit for customer use (marked as "noAPI" in the Cloudification Repository) 

By understanding Levels (A, B, C, D) we can make architectural decisions that balance technical purity with operational reality, prioritizing business stability and flexibility.... But Important!!: Beyond the levels, a Clean Core strategy requires governance. The fundamental principle is: Extensions must be avoided when possible. Before, we must to evaluate if standard functionality covers the process. If the extension is inevitable, we must ensure that extensions don't break Upgrades
To decide between an On-stack or Side-by-side implementation, customers should use the SAP Application Extension Methodology. This methodology helps to define a custom extension strategy. It addresses challenges like "clean core" by offering a structured, standard approach. This ensures a common understanding and terminology and it allows to assess technical options and make informed decisions to build an extension framework for your organization.

---
Bookmark this SAP Note: 3578329 - Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility 
Official list of framework and technology classifications that will tell you what is Level A, B, C, or D

New Cloudification Repository Viewer for Clean Core Governance and Development
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/new-cloudification-repository-viewer-for-clean-core-governance-and/ba-p/14236110

entry.title: Re: Employee Central - Business Rule to default country i...
entry.content:
Hi @mkrieg,

Yes, you can write a simple rule to check for the specific legal entities (for which the rule should be triggered) and make the country field non-editable. If the number of those LEs is small, then you can put them in the rule itself, or you can create a custom MDF object to maintain the LEs. If the employee's LE is matched, then the rule defaults the country field from the jobInfo record. 

You might have to consider the following:

- You might have to create an onSave rule, as an onInit rule might not be triggered on homeAddress.

- In specific scenarios, the employee's home address country might be different from the LE country.

- You might have to handle Global assignment and concurrent employment cases, if applicable.

Regards,

Jayendra

entry.title: Re: Why Excluded Filters in BW query not working in sap a...
entry.content: Yes this is by design in SAP Analytics Cloud because in live BW on HANA connections excluded filters are fully respected in tables but charts handle filter evaluation differently during aggregation, so excluded selections from the BW query may appear ignored in charts, and this is a known limitation of chart rendering in live BW scenarios, with the usual workaround being to redesign the BW query filter logic, use restricted key figures, or validate results using tables instead of charts.

entry.title: Re: Unposted values in SAP Analytics Cloud Headmap
entry.content: In SAP Analytics Cloud heatmaps do not support unposted or unbooked values for live BW queries because heatmaps require fully aggregated posted data for color calculation, while tables can display unposted values directly from the query result set, so this is a known limitation by design and there is no workaround other than using a table or posting the data.

entry.title: Leveraging AI for a perfect SAP case ticket creation in SAP For Me
entry.content:
This is a two parts blog articulating the effective use of AI tools for perfect SAP case ticket creation, for getting the best value from SAP Support Services.

Part 1:  Leveraging AI tools for a perfect SAP case ticket creation

Part 2: Leveraging AI tools for effective business impact driven priortization

In Part 2,  let's explore how to leverage AI tools for crafting an effective business impact statement for right prioritization and triaging for speedy processing of P1-Very High and P2-High tickets.

SAP for Me has transitioned to an Impact-Driven Prioritization model where your business impact statement directly determines your ticket's priority level. Using AI tools like Joule or external LLMs (e.g., ChatGPT, Perplexity, Claude) can help you draft these statements to meet SAP's stringent requirements and avoid resolution delays. 

  1. Structure Your AI Prompt

To generate a perfect statement, provide your AI agent with these core data points based on SAP's mandatory criteria: 

  • System Status: Is the system completely unavailable or just a specific module?
  • Business Process: Which specific process is stopped (e.g., monthly payroll run, year-end closing)?
  • Quantifiable Impact: How many users are affected? What is the estimated financial loss per day?
  • Deadlines: Are there impending legal or project go-live deadlines (include exact dates)?
  • Workaround: State clearly if a workaround exists and why it is not feasible for long-term use.

2. AI-Assisted Writing within SAP for Me

When creating a case in the Get Support application:

  • Text Prompts: Use the integrated AI text prompts to guide your input. These prompts are designed to extract the most relevant details for SAP engineers.
  • Categorization: AI predictor services in SAP for Me analyze your short description to automatically recommend the correct product component, ensuring your impact statement reaches the right expert team immediately.

3. Checklist for High/Very High (Critically Affected) Priority

For critical cases, your AI-generated statement must include these "non-negotiable" details to maintain the priority level:

  • 24/7 Contact: Provide a primary and secondary contact available 24/7 who can speak English.
  • Quantified Financials: Instead of saying "major impact," use AI to calculate quanitified financial loss to the business: "Issue affects 500+ employees and delays a $2M monthly billing cycle".
  • Project Milestones: For non-production systems, clearly list the Go-Live date and explain if the issue is a "showstopper" for that milestone.

4. Sample AI Prompt for a Support Case

Copy and adapt this prompt for your AI assistant:

"Write a professional  SAP Business Impact statement for a 'Critically Affected' support ticket. The issue is that the [Module Name] is not generating [Specific Document Type]. It affects [Number] of users. Our go-live date is [Date], and this is a showstopper because [Reason]. There is no workaround. Financial impact is estimated at $[Amount] per day".

4. Essential SAP Documentation

For further guidance on priority definitions and case management, refer to these official resources:

  • SAP Note 67739: Official definitions for priority levels (Low to Very High).
  • SAP Note 1281633: How to speed up the processing of a case.

Optimize and transform the way SAP Support tickets are raised with the aid of AI but with caution and responsiblity.

entry.title: Leveraging AI for a perfect SAP case ticket creation in SAP For Me
entry.content:
This is a two parts blog articulating the effective use of AI tools for perfect SAP case ticket creation, for getting the best value from SAP Support Services.

Part 1:  Leveraging AI tools for a perfect SAP case ticket creation

Part 2: Leveraging AI tools for effective business impact driven priortization

In Part 1, let us explore innovative ways for creating a perfect SAP SuccessFactors support case which involves leveraging SAP's latest Support assistant (powered by AI), Joule, and the SAP for Me ecosystem to automate the technical details that support engineers need. 

  1. Leverage the SAP Check Tool

Before manually drafting a ticket, use the built-in Check Tool to identify and classify issues automatically. 

  • Run the Check: Navigate to Admin Center > Check Tool and execute the relevant tests for your module (e.g., Employee Central, Recruiting).
  • Direct Ticket Creation: If the tool finds an error it cannot resolve, select the "Need Assistance?" section on the Result tab to create a case directly.
  • Automatic Data Capture: Creating a ticket this way automatically attaches critical Component IDs (e.g., LOD-SF-EC) and system logs, ensuring the case is routed to the correct expert immediately. 

2. Use Support Assistant for Problem Description 

When writing the "Problem Description" in the SAP for Me portal, either use any external AI-assisted writing tool to refine your text for clarity or use the inbuilt Support Assistant. In the SAP for Me portal, the Support Assistant/Get Support feature is an AI-enabled, conversational guided tool designed to suggest solutions, classify problems, and recommend the best channel (like Expert Chat, Schedule an Expert, or creating a Case) for faster resolution.

 Structure Your Input: Provide the AI agent with these four essential elements:

    • Specific Issue: "All applicants fail to receive emails when moved to 'Hired' status".
    • Expected Behavior: "Candidates should receive configured email notifications based on the Applicant Status Configuration".
    • Step-by-Step Replication: Ask the AI to format your notes into a numbered list (e.g., "1. Log into test environment; 2. Proxy as User X; 3. Move Candidate Y...").
    • Business Impact: Clearly define if the issue is Minimally, Moderately, Seriously, or Critically effected. Refer to the blog's Part 2 for crafting an effective Business Impact using effective AI Prompting for critically effected issues.

3. Provide Mandatory Technical Context 

Provide these mandatory details to prevent "back-and-forth" delays: 

  • Instance Details: Include your Data Center, Company ID, and specific Client/System ID.
  • User Details: Provide the specific User ID or Candidate Name used for testing.
  • Visual Evidence: Attach uncropped screenshots that show the full browser address bar to help SAP engineers verify your environment.

4. Ensure "Premium AI" Support Readiness (New for 2025)

If your issue specifically involves SAP‚Äôs new generative AI features (e.g., Joule or SAP Generative AI Use cases), verify your setup: 

  • Premium Features: Check if your usage exceeds your annual allocation, as these are classified as "Premium AI" features.
  • Permissions: Confirm that the "Manage AI Capabilities" permission is active in Role-Based Permissions (RBP), as this is often required for support to investigate AI-specific failures. 

Hope this blog details how to effectively use SAP‚Äôs AI assistant and Check Tool for creating support tickets and ensuring proper context is provided for a speedy processing by Support Engineers, thereby significantly minimising the overall ticket processing time.  üëâ Click here for reading Part 2 of the blog.

entry.title: Re: SAP BW BEx query structures replication/creation in S...
entry.content: SAP Analytics Cloud does not support direct replication of SAP BW BEx query structures inside a story because structures are handled at BW query level, so the same behavior can be achieved only by creating equivalent restricted or calculated measures in the BW query or SAC model, or by redesigning the logic using measures, filters, and charts in SAC, as there is no one to one structure concept available in SAC stories.

entry.title: SAP Integrated Business Planning On Demand - Stay Secure with SAP EarlyWatch Alert
entry.content:
With SAP Integrated Business Planning On Demand, SAP takes care of many security-related topics as cloud provider. However, in order to stay secure, customers are still responsible for the mitigation of risks such as business or technical users having critical authorizations.

Here, the SAP EarlyWatch Alert report in SAP for Me comes into play as it gives you insights into security risks in the chapter "Security (SAP IBP OD)". This chapter provides insights and alerts you on the following topics:

  • Assignment of Users to Business Role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR - check for usage of this role in production, leading to segregation of duties (SoD) conflicts as it is intended only for initial system configuration
  • Use of Read/Write Unrestricted - get alerts on business roles with unrestricted write, read and value help access, allowing users global data access
  • Critical Business Catalog Assignment - be warned about over-assignment of critical authorizations which should have limited use in production
  • Critical Authorization Combinations - get alerts for users assigned excess authorizations through critical combinations of business catalogs
  • Communication (Inbound/Outbound) - get alerts on customer-managed communication arrangements based on user/password authentication, where certificate-based authentication is more secure
  • Upcoming Certificate Expiration - get early warnings for customer-managed certificates which will expire within the next 90 days

You can find more details on each of these chapters below or by directly accessing the SAP EarlyWatch Alert report* for your systems in SAP for Me. 
* an authorized user is needed to access this application - refer to this SAP Support page on how to get access.

Assignment of Users to Business Role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR

The role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR is predefined by SAP and is intended only for the initial configuration of a system. Using this role in production is not recommended by SAP and may lead to compliance issues. This section checks the role's usage and points to in-depth information on Identity Access Management. It provides a link to the procedure for creating a more restricted administration role, suitable for use in production.

Use of Read/Write Unrestricted

Using unrestricted fields in the maintenance of business roles allow users to have global data access. SAP best practices recommend to carefully review which users need to have restricted data access and maintain the access appropriately, e.g. ensuring employees only have access to data belonging to their sales organization. This chapter includes the number of business roles with unrestricted write, read or value help access, and describes the related SAP Fiori app Maintain Business Roles.

Use of Read/Write Unrestricted Table Example

 

Critical Business Catalog Assignment

Business catalogs contain a bundle of privileges needed for accessing an app or features that are then assigned to users via business roles. This section checks for selected critical business catalogs and their assignment to business roles and users and rates this according to the valuation rules from SAP Note 863362. In case any critical business catalogs are assigned, additional details are presented as sub-chapters.

Business Catalog Assignments Overview Table Example

 

Critical Authorization Combinations

Segregation of duties in SAP Integrated Business Planning (SAP IBP) is supported by the use of business catalogs and business roles. Creatinga a business role by combining catalogs may grant excess authorization to users and lead to a negative impact on your business processes. The section gives user counts where such critical combinations are found, with a link to information on assessing the associated risks.

Communication (Inbound/Outbound)

Certificate-based communication is recommended for technical users involved in inbound/outbound communication. It is usually easier to detect a compromised certificate than to detect a compromised password. This section lists customer-managed communication arrangements that are password-based, and points to recommendations for a certificate-based approach.

Upcoming Certificate Expiration

Certificates with an expiration date in the next 90 days are listed in this section, with alerts for certifcates where a short-term expiration under 30 days is found.

entry.title: Important Update: Renew Your Adobe ReaderRights Credential for SAP Interactive Forms
entry.content:
A quick heads-up for customers using SAP Interactive Forms by Adobe on NetWeaver JAVA: Please check the validity of your Adobe ReaderRights credential. The current credential is valid only until Thursday, January 1, 2026.

You must request a new credential and replace the old one by the stated date. If the credential is not renewed prior to this date, you will no longer be able to generate interactive forms.

For more information, please refer to the following SAP Note published on SAP Hot News:
736902 - Adobe Credentials

This KBA describes the steps to verify the expiry date of your current Adobe ReaderRights credential:
2860179 - How to install a Reader Rights Credential in NWA

To request new version credential file: Please open a Support Case to SAP on component BC-SRV-FP-ICF. Ensure that your contact email address is maintained in your S-User account, as the credential will be sent to it. SAP will then proceed to generate and deliver the credential file.

entry.title: Standard CDS Views that helped me load Master Data for SAC Planning
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

With any SAC Planning implementation project, there is always a requirement to load the master data and Transaction Data before we begin with the input sheets, Data actions and so on. In most of the SAC Planning scenarios, the required dimensions would most likely remain the same. So why spend energy when SAP provides us with all the detailed high quality information we need.

Eg:-
For Sales --> Country, Profit Center, Product Group, Segment, Trading Partner, Company code.
For Opex --> Cost Center
For Capex --> Asset Class, Material Group, Transaction Type

In order to populate the master dimensions, we needn't write any custom Views or logic to achieve it, that is where Standard CDS Views comes into the picture. The official SAP documentation provides many Standard CDS views for the individual LOBs.
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/5418de55938d1d22e10000000a44147b.html

Some of these CDS views even come with a view that holds the text description data for that field.

Public Dimension

CDS View Name

Z_Country

A_Country

A_CountryText

Z_PROFIT_CENTER

A_Profitcenter

A_ProfitcenterText

Z_PRODUCTGROUP

I_ProductGroup2

Z_SEGMENT

A_Segment

A_SegmentText

Z_TRADING_PARTNER

I_PartnerCompany

Z_COMPANYCODE

A_CompanyCode

Z_COSTCENTER

A_Costcenter

A_CostcenterText

Z_TRANSACTION_TYPE

FinancialTransactionType

Z_ASSET_CLASS

I_AssetClassStdVH

Z_MATERIAL_GROUP

I_MaterialGroup


I hope this information helps you with your Project and makes your life easier. I will try sharing more tips and tricks which helped me through some of the projects I've faced. Feel free to share your opinion or doubts in the comment section below.

With regards,
Siva Prakash.

entry.title: Performance Issue in SAP Commerce APIs Resolved Using Fastly Pass Method
entry.content:
We recently encountered a performance issue in our SAP Commerce application where two specific Ajax APIs were taking significantly longer to respond for one particular country. And we observed that with '='(/order/dataFlyout?varientcode=) and without '=' (/order/dataFlyout?varientcode) also response time was different. 

The issue was isolated two requests coming from a specific country, while other regions were unaffected. This caused delays in critical API calls and impacted user experience.

Fastly team implemented the pass method in our Fastly VCL script for these APIs. This resolved our issue.

Client believes that this is a issue with Hybris Code. To fix this is there anything we can do in hybris systems like code changes etc. Fastly team is also suggesting that this is not Fastly issue and Application team needs to check this. 

Thanks,

Krishna.

entry.title: Empowering Teams to Streamline Sales and Service Operations with SAP Build Joule Skills
entry.content:
üåüIntroduction to SAP Build Joule Skills

In today‚Äôs fast-changing business landscape, automation, intelligence, and integration are essential for success. SAP Build Joule Skills bring these elements together to help businesses optimize workflows, streamline project management, and automate repetitive processes like project opportunity creation, quote management, and customer service handling.

By combining SAP Joule‚Äôs intelligent automation with SAP‚Äôs enterprise-grade solutions, organizations can increase productivity, ensure accuracy, and empower employees to focus on high-value work.

üö®Please refer to the video for better understanding.üö®

ü§ñWhat Are SAP Build Joule Skills?

SAP Build Joule Skills are customizable automation capabilities built within the SAP ecosystem. They allow users to create intelligent workflows that respond to business needs ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs creating new sales opportunities, generating quotes, or handling service requests.

‚ú®Key Features of Joule Skills:

  • Automation: Reduce manual data entry by automating repetitive tasks.
  • Integration: Connect seamlessly with SAP and non-SAP systems.
  • Scalability: Create and manage skills that grow with your organization.
  • User-Friendly: Empower business users with low-code/no-code design tools.

üß† What Is SAP Build Joule?

SAP Build Joule is part of the SAP Build portfolio ‚Äî a low-code platform that enables business and IT users to collaboratively design, automate, and innovate processes. Joule brings an AI-powered digital assistant into this ecosystem, helping users perform complex tasks through simple, conversational interactions.

ü™Ñ Key Benefits:

  • Accelerated automation ‚Äì Build and deploy workflows faster.
  • No-code customization ‚Äì Design automation logic without needing deep technical skills.
  • AI-driven insights ‚Äì Use AI to make decisions faster and improve efficiency.

üåüStory:

It was another busy morning at Conva Engineering. Adrian Chase, an account manager, had a full agenda ‚Äî new project sites to manage and quotes to prepare for contractors working across the site, and a customer issue waiting for resolution.

In the past, this would have meant hours of manual coordination: filling out spreadsheets, sending multiple emails, and ensuring every quote aligned with customer requirements. But since his company adopted SAP Joule, Adrian‚Äôs workday looks very different.

He starts his day by opening SAP Joule, the AI-powered assistant integrated within the company‚Äôs SAP landscapes.

‚ÄúJoule, please create a new project.‚Äù

Joule instantly responds:

‚ÄúSure, please provide the site name, customer, and materials to be quoted.‚Äù

Adrian enters the details: the site name ‚ÄúFree Text‚Äù, the customer details, and three product codes ‚Äî 5079, 5080, and 5081.

Within moments, Joule creates the new project opportunity, generates the required quotes for the contractors bidding on the site contract, and organizes all related data within the project opportunity.

Later that morning, when a damaged product report comes in from a client, Adrian simply instructs Joule to raise a credit request.

‚ÄúA service case has been created and linked to the project,‚Äù Joule confirms.

Without opening multiple applications or chasing emails, the issue is automatically routed to customer service with sales order data for processing the credit extracted via AI, ensuring a fast response and complete traceability.

By leveraging SAP Joule, Adrian has transformed what used to be a time-consuming, manual process into an intelligent, automated workflow.

Now, he spends less time managing tasks ‚Äî and more time building relationships, exploring new opportunities, and driving strategic growth.

üß© SAP Products That Power Joule Skills

SAP Joule Skills are designed to work seamlessly across multiple SAP solutions, forming a connected ecosystem for business excellence. Here are some key SAP products that enhance and integrate with Joule:

‚öôÔ∏èSAP Build

  • The foundation for creating Joule Skills.
  • Allows both business users and developers to design, automate, and test workflows through a low-code environment.

üßæ SAP S/4HANA Cloud

  • Central to managing projects, quotes, and sales orders.
  • Joule connects directly with S/4HANA data to fetch customer, product, and pricing details in real time.

üí¨SAP Sales Cloud

  • Integrates with Joule to streamline the quote-to-order process.
  • Ensures sales teams can generate accurate quotes and track opportunities efficiently.

ü§ùSAP Customer Experience (CX)

  • Improves collaboration between sales and customer support.
  • Joule automates ticket creation, credit requests, and case tracking for customer satisfaction.

üß∞ SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

  • The underlying infrastructure that connects all SAP solutions.
  • Ensures secure, scalable, and high-performance integration between Joule Skills and enterprise systems.

üíºUse Case: Project Opportunity & Quote Creation

Let‚Äôs look at a real-world example featuring Adrian Chase, a sales professional who uses SAP Joule to manage project opportunities, quotes, and service requests seamlessly.

Step 1: Create a New Project

Arian launches the Joule app from his workspace and starts a new project. Joule asks for key information such as the site name, customer details, and materials to be quoted.

Step 2:Create Opportunity

 

Opportunity created in Sales Cloud V2.

The Same Opportunity  is replicated to S4HANA public cloud as an Project 

 

S4HANA Customer Project replication from V2 Sales Opportunity 

 

Step 3: Create a Quote and Associate It with the Existing Opportunity

 

Every quote created is associated with an existing opportunity

Step 4: Handle Service Requests

Arian needs to issue a credit for a damaged product.

 

Case created is associated with an existing opportunity

 

Final 

 

Video

 

 

üöÄWhy Joule Skills Matter for Businesses

1. Time Efficiency

  • Automate manual processes like project setup, quote generation, and service requests to save time.

2. Accuracy & Data Consistency

  • Reduce errors through system-driven data capture and validation.

3. Improved Collaboration

  • Connect sales, service, and operations teams through unified data flows.

4. Scalable Innovation

  • Quickly adapt Joule Skills to handle new business needs without complex development.

5. AI-Powered Productivity

  • Leverage SAP Joule‚Äôs conversational AI to guide employees through complex workflows.

 

üåàConclusion

SAP Build Joule Skills empower organizations to automate end-to-end workflows, from project creation to customer service handling. When combined with SAP Build, SAP S/4HANA, Sales Cloud, and CX, Joule becomes a central intelligence hub that drives efficiency, consistency, and growth.

By integrating your business processes into Joule Skills, you can:

  • Reduce operational overhead,
  • Enhance customer satisfaction, and
  • Enable teams to focus on strategic goals.

üí°Start building your Joule Skills today ‚Äî and transform the way your business works with the power of SAP!

entry.title: Stop Building From Scratch: Unlocking SAP Cloud Integration‚Äôs Standard Content
entry.content:
A few months ago, I joined a project where the integration team was spending weeks designing mappings, data models, and error-handling frameworks for processes that were all quite common in business environments.

Sales Orders, Customers, Accounts and other Business Objects

The system landscape was straightforward:
SAP S/4HANA on the backend, Salesforce as the CRM, and the business just wanted data to flow seamlessly between the two.

The team had already started building everything manually:

  • Canonical models for Business Partners
  • Transformations to Salesforce Accounts
  • Retry frameworks and error handling
After Six weeks of design workshops, not a single iFlow was built yet.
At one point, I asked: ‚ÄúHave we checked the Discover space in SAP CI for pre-built Salesforce content?‚Äù
The answer was a confident:  "No. We always build our own.‚Äù
 
Fast forward a few hours later, we sat together and opened Discover.

Most of what they were planning to design had already been developed by SAP, ready to use, specifically for S/4HANA to Salesforce integration, available in the Discover space of SAP Cloud Integration.

There are pre-built integration flows for:

  • Business Partner ‚Üî Account
  • Order ‚Üî Opportunity status
  • Customer master synchronization
  • Error handling and notifications

Instead of designing everything from scratch, all they needed to do was deploy, configure, and extend where necessary.

And this experience has repeated itself across multiple customers, industries, and systems, teams spending months designing integrations that SAP had already delivered as out-of-the-box content.

Not because the team enjoy reinventing the wheel,
but because they simply didn‚Äôt know the wheel already existed.

So, this blog is for everyone who is still building everything from scratch, not because they want to, but because they don‚Äôt know that SAP already provides out-of-the-box integration content.

 

What Is Standard Integration Content?

In simple terms, it‚Äôs SAP‚Äôs way of saying: ‚ÄúHere are prebuilt integration flows, mappings, APIs, and business objects. You don‚Äôt need to start from zero.‚Äù

This content is:

  • Built by SAP
  • Delivered as part of your Integration Suite license
  • Designed for common business processes
  • Packaged with best practices and enterprise patterns

Think of it as Lego blocks.
SAP gives you the pieces, and you assemble what fits your scenario.

 

But How Much Content Are We Talking About?

Here‚Äôs the scale people don‚Äôt realize:

700+ Integration Packages and nearly 4000 iFlows delivered out-of-the-box by SAP.

 

This isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúsome content‚Äù.
It‚Äôs an entire ecosystem of reusable assets built to accelerate enterprise integration.

 

Reality Check: Actual time needed to build integrations

In many organizations, a typical integration project goes like this:

Classic approach (manual build)

  • 6‚Äì8 weeks of design
  • 6‚Äì10 weeks of development
  • Testing + refinements

Total: 12‚Äì20 weeks

 

With Standard Integration Content

  • Deploy existing flows
  • Configure mappings
  • Tailor business-specific logic

Total: 2‚Äì6 weeks

What‚Äôs in the Box?

Standard content includes:
  • Pre-built iFlows
  • Value mappings
  • Event-based integrations
  • Error handling logic
  • Industry-specific templates
  • Configuration Guide
Some packages even include complete integration scenarios. You don‚Äôt just get sample content, You get deployment-ready accelerators.
 

Out-of-the-Box‚Äù Means Out-of-the-Budget

Here‚Äôs the part that surprises most people: There is no additional cost for this. As long as you have a valid license for SAP Integration Suite, you already have access to the standard integration content.

There‚Äôs no marketplace fee.
There‚Äôs no premium tier.
There‚Äôs no ‚Äúenterprise unlock‚Äù.

 

Where Do You Find It?

If you‚Äôve never explored it, here‚Äôs how to get started:
  1. Open SAP Integration Suite
  2. Go to Discover
  3. Search for apps or domains (e.g., SuccessFactors, Salesforce, Ariba)

 

  1. Review package
  2. Copy and adapt

 

As soon as you copy the package, it gets visible in the design tab of your tenant, Now the package is ready to be used. You can configure, modify and make it ready to use.

If you‚Äôre new to SAP CI, take 30 minutes and browse, it will change how you approach integration forever.

 

Why Use Standard Content?

Here‚Äôs the business value:
  1. Faster delivery
    Skip the blueprinting for obvious processes.
  2. Lower risk
    SAP delivers content that is tested, versioned, and updated.
  3. SAP Support and Maintenance
    Support is provided by SAP and updates are released if any.
  4. Best practices by default
    You don‚Äôt have to reinvent canonical models or data mappings.
  5. More time for innovation
    Deliver outcomes, not just interfaces.

My favorite way to summarize it: SAP builds 70-80% of the technical plumbing. You only customize what makes your business unique.

 

Customize, Don‚Äôt Copy-Paste

A common misconception is: ‚ÄúStandard content means I have to use it the way it comes.‚Äù
The answer is: "No"

You can:

  • Extend mappings
  • Add enrichment logic
  • Build wrapper services
  • Add error or retry mechanisms

 SAP expects you to tailor it.

The goal is not reuse OR customize.
The goal is reuse AND customize smartly.

But here‚Äôs a very important nuance that many teams overlook:

When you directly modify a standard integration flow, SAP continues to support the standard baseline, but not the customized version. From that point on, you own the lifecycle of the changes.  And honestly, it makes complete sense. Because once you‚Äôve edited it, SAP has no visibility into:

  • What you changed
  • Why you changed it
  • Whether your changes break functional assumptions

 So they can‚Äôt be accountable for something they didn‚Äôt design or test.

This doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúdon‚Äôt customize‚Äù.

There are smarter patterns teams follow to balance reuse + support:

  • Overlay mappings instead of rewriting
  • Wrap standard content in a parent orchestrator
  • Avoid editing the original package unless absolutely necessary
  • Clone only when you fully ‚Äúown‚Äù the lifecycle

 In other words:

Standard content should be reused wherever feasible and extended cautiously when required. Customization should be undertaken only when full ownership and support responsibility can be assumed, ensuring faster delivery and long-term stability.
 

But Let‚Äôs Be Honest

Standard content is not perfect.

Sometimes:

  • The business process doesn‚Äôt match your reality
  • Documentation is light
  • Customization becomes unavoidable

That‚Äôs okay. Think of standard content as a foundation, not a finished building.

It saves you weeks of work.Not all the work.

 

The Mindset Shift

The biggest barrier to adoption is not technology, its culture. Many Integration Teams have this default behavior:
‚ÄúOpen Integration Suite ‚Üí Create iFlow ‚Üí Start designing‚Äù
But the better question is: ‚ÄúHas SAP already solved this problem for me?‚Äù
 
We don‚Äôt get awards for reinventing wheels, We get value from delivering outcomes faster.
 

Real-World Examples

Here are real scenarios where standard content gave teams a head start:
  • Salesforce Integration with SAP Signavio Process Intelligence
  • SAP S/4HANA Integration with Coupa
  • SAP S/4HANA Integration with Zycus

What would normally take 6-8 weeks of design + development
sometimes went live in 2-3 weeks with tailoring.

 

Wrapping Up

SAP Cloud Integration doesn‚Äôt just give you a platform. It gives you content, knowledge, and patterns out-of-the-box.
And yet, so many organizations overlook it spending time, budget, and energy on things that are already there.
 
So the next time someone says: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll build the integration from scratch.‚Äù
Ask them: ‚ÄúOr should we check what SAP already provides?‚Äù
It‚Äôs a small question with massive impact.
 

Join the Conversation

Standard Integration Content in SAP CI continues to grow because practitioners share real-world experiences, gaps, and ideas. If you come across a business scenario or integration use case where standard content is missing or doesn‚Äôt fully meet your needs, don‚Äôt keep it to yourself, share it in the comments or reach out. Your feedback truly matters.

Have you already used Standard Integration Content in SAP Cloud Integration? What worked well, what didn‚Äôt, and what surprised you along the way? Share your experiences, lessons, and tips, because the SAP community learns fastest when we learn together and every insight helps make the standard content more relevant for everyone.

Hope this helps!

 

Cheers,
Punith

entry.title: Joule Capability Documentation Chat
entry.content:
As use cases involving AI become increasingly intertwined with our lives, we have developed a documentation chat for ABAP developers. The documentation chat is available for you to ask questions and find solutions to any ABAP development problem you may have. The conversation with the documentation chat should help you solve your tasks and serve as your helpful guide.

In this blog, we explain the rationale behind the documentation chat, how to use it, and what it offers in SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2511.

 

Rationale

Our primary goal is to provide easy access to the ABAP Cloud product documentation and to enhance the accessibility and findability of our content. Finding documentation has always been an issue that‚Äôs often caused by missing semantics in the provided content. To address this issue, we employ retrieval-augmented generation to deliver relevant information in response to a query.

 

Using the Documentation Chat

The documentation chat is available as a Joule capability in ABAP development tools for Eclipse. For information about using Joule in ABAP development tools for Eclipse, refer to Opening the Joule Chat View.

To use the documentation chat, follow these steps:

  1. In the Joule view, select the button /.
  2. Choose docs.

    If you send the request without a prompt, you receive a description of the capability.
  3. Enter your question in the text area.

     



  4. Press Enter or select the Select message (Enter) button.

    You receive a response to your question. The answer can include text, bullet points, and code examples. Also, references are always provided, allowing you to view the source documentation and verify the given answer.

 

Supported Documentation

As of SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2511, the documentation chat includes the following documentation:

  • ABAP Keyword Documentation
  • ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model
  • ABAP Data Models
  • ABAP Cloud

When chatting with the documentation, you can expect assistance with the topics in the documentation above. It is also possible to ask follow-up questions after an initial question, as the chat history is respected.

In the coming releases, you can expect more to come. Feel free to leave a comment or a like.

entry.title: Re: Quantity Distribution settings
entry.content:
Good day @LK_WF 

Thank you for your question

You mentioned using the quantity distribution described in the Blog you attached to your question. However, there might have been a slight misunderstanding in the approach.

The key point in that blog is:

Quantity Distribution spreads the goods receipt quantity across the production cycle based on the order runtime. This distribution happens between the order planned start and planned end, not between scheduled start and planned end.

To summarise, in public cloud, Quantity Distribution distributes quantities over the runtime of the supply element (for example a planned or production order). This means that between the order planned start and planned end. It does not extend the distribution horizon to include additional slack buffers.

Regarding you question on customisation availability: i am not aware of any standard customisation that allows you to change the distribution horizon as you require. Note that Quantity distribution is tied to the order runtime dates, while the slack you mentioned is driven by Scheduling Margin Key. See the references https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2bba750d1e124e1ea2a039bb1cd9b6c5/9c6afca5b8714062aaa44cefc430a148.html?locale=en-US & https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2bba750d1e124e1ea2a039bb1cd9b6c5/9aabce5314894208e10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US for more details.

A practical workaround if your goal is to have your distribution horizon behave closer to your desired timeline, is to influence it indirectly by changing the dates:

  • Reduce or remove your Scheduling Margin Key (floats) so that the gap between your planned and scheduled dates is minimised. See Configuring Production Order Scheduling and  Calculating Production Dates (Lead Time Scheduling) for more insights.
  • Make sure your GR processing time is maintained and scheduled as intended because it affects the receipt availability timing, not a separate distribution horizon setting.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: New Where-Used Functionality in PMEVC for Objects in Knowledge-Base Runtime Versions
entry.content:
We're excited to introduce a new feature in the VC Modeling Environment (PMEVC) that helps you track objects in your existing knowledge-base (KB) runtime versions more efficiently. This enhancement addresses a common challenge: determining which KB runtime versions are affected when you modify a VC object. The feature is available with SAP Note 3645167.

Previously, there was no straightforward way to identify which KB runtime versions included a specific VC object. When you made changes to objects like variant tables, classes, characteristics, or dependencies, you had to manually track which runtime versions needed regeneration to incorporate these changes in a new build of the KB runtime version.

The solution: KB-Usage Overview in PMEVC

The new functionality in PMEVC provides a comprehensive KB-usage overview for VC objects, including:

  • Materials
  • Variant Tables
  • Classes
  • Characteristics
  • Global Dependencies

The key features are the following:

  1. Usage in KB Tab: A new tab called "Usage in KB" has been added to the detail screens of these objects. This tab displays all KB runtime versions that include the object.

new tab: Usage in KB

  1. Detailed Information: For each KB runtime version, you can see these fields:
    • KBID
    • KB Build
    • Valid-from Date
    • KB Object Name
    • KB Version
    • Plant
    • BOM Application
    • Change Date
    • Changer
    • KB Schema
  2. Regeneration Capability: You can now easily regenerate listed KB runtime versions directly from the screen using the new "Generate" button next to each KB runtime version in the list.

How It Works

The functionality is based on the function module KB_WUL_SELECT, which retrieves knowledge-base usage information. This module uses two mandatory input parameters:

  • OBJECT_NAME: The name of the VC object
  • OBJECT_TYPE: The type of VC object, specified using these acronyms:
    • VTA: Variant Table
    • DEP: Dependency
    • CLA: Class
    • MAT: Material
    • CHR: Characteristic

These optional parameters allow you to refine your search:

  • Validity Range (with valid-from and valid-to dates)
  • Class Type
  • Flag to search only in SCE tables instead.

Benefits for Modelers

This new functionality significantly improves the modeling experience by:

  • Saving time previously spent manually tracking KB runtime version usage.
  • Reducing errors by ensuring all affected runtime versions are identified.
  • Simplifying the regeneration process with direct access from the usage list.

We're confident this enhancement will make your work more efficient and accurate. Try it out and experience the improved workflow for managing KB runtime versions!

Want to make the most of your knowledge bases? Check out our Best Practice Guide.

entry.title: Turning SAP Business AI into People and Culture Intelligence
entry.content:
Turning SAP Business AI into People and Culture Intelligence

How SAP and its partners are applying AI to recognition, rewards, and manager support
Co-authored by Ivana Maznevska (Semos Cloud) and Kathrin Hettel (SAP)

 

From AI Experiments to People and Culture Intelligence

Most enterprises have moved past the "experiment with chatbots" phase of AI. The questions are no longer "Which model should we try?" or "Can we generate text?" They are "What are we allowed to do with employee data?" and "How do we embed AI in the places where work already happens?"

In People & Culture, this execution constraint is especially visible. Organizations sit on rich data: recognition patterns, performance history, learning progress, engagement signals, well-being indicators. Managers have access to more dashboards than ever before, but they rarely have time to open another report or log into another app.

People and Culture Intelligence turns this raw data into signals about recognition, growth, sentiment, and risk that managers and leaders can act on. It means AI that understands business context and surfaces insights inside SAP solutions and tools people already use, whether that's SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA, or Joule, rather than leaving them in reports that never get opened.

This is where platform and partner work together. SAP provides the secure, AI-ready foundation. Partners take that foundation and apply it to specific People & Culture use cases. Here is how that looks in practice.

SAP Business AI as a foundation for people and culture intelligence

For any AI application touching employee data, governance is not optional. People & Culture systems hold performance history, compensation details, feedback, and sensitive information that require enterprise-grade protection.

The SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) Generative AI Hub provides the core layer for building secure, business-ready AI applications. It gives customers and partners access to leading Large Language Models while maintaining control over how those models are used. Behind the scenes, SAP AI Foundation services handle critical tasks such as data masking, input filtering, centralized prompt management, and audit trails.

For People & Culture scenarios, this architecture matters because the intelligence being built often draws on HR, employee experience, and performance data. With the help of SAP Business AI, partners can ensure employee data remains protected, and results remain trustworthy when building customer use cases.

‚ÄúPeople and Culture is one of the most sensitive and impactful domains for AI. Organizations expect intelligence that helps managers and HR teams act, while maintaining absolute trust in how employee data is handled. The SAP BTP Generative AI Hub provides a governed foundation where innovation and responsibility go hand in hand, enabling partners to build People & Culture solutions that embed data protection, compliance, and transparency by design.‚Äù

Kathrin Hettel ‚Äì VP, Strategic Cross-Portfolio and AI Partnerships at SAP

Why Partners Matter in Turning Data into Decisions

SAP provides the platform and core AI capabilities. Partners bring domain specialization.

In People & Culture, that specialization means understanding local cultures, recognition norms, manager time pressure, and the practical constraints of HR teams. It also means building solutions that respect existing processes, compliance requirements, and organizational realities.

Partners like Semos Cloud build solutions that sit natively inside the SAP landscape: integrated with SAP SuccessFactors and SAP S/4HANA, aligned with SAP UX patterns, and specialized enough to solve problems that generic tools cannot address.

This combination, SAP's platform and the partner ecosystem, is how People and Culture Intelligence becomes operational.

Co-Innovation in Practice: SAP Appreciate and Joule Integration

The clearest example of SAP and partner co-innovation in People & Culture is SAP Appreciate, SAP's internal global recognition and rewards program.

SAP Appreciate has been running since 2016 and is available to SAP's workforce across more than 140 countries. The program shows what recognition looks like when it is embedded in the way people already work. Employees use it to send appreciation aligned to SAP values. Managers and HR leaders can see how recognition flows across regions, teams, and roles over time. Culture trends become visible rather than staying hidden in one-off thank-you messages.

Semos Cloud's platform underpins SAP Appreciate, running on SAP BTP and integrated bidirectionally with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central. Over the years, the program has successfully moved between SAP platform generations, from SAP BTP Neo to Cloud Foundry and onward to SAP HANA Cloud, without losing historical data or disrupting employees.

More recently, this co-innovation has extended to SAP's generative AI capabilities. Semos Cloud became the first SAP Spotlight Partner to integrate recognition directly into Joule, SAP's AI copilot. Employees can now recognize colleagues, link recognitions to company values, and share appreciation all within their SAP workspace, with no additional apps or logins required. This integration brings recognition into the natural flow of daily work, removing the friction that often prevents appreciation from happening in the moment.

This is what co-innovation looks like: a long-running program, deep platform integration, and continuous extension as SAP's AI capabilities evolve.

Extending People & Culture Intelligence Across the Employee Experience

Recognition is one domain. But the same co-innovation pattern extends across the broader People & Culture landscape.

Partners working with SAP are building solutions that address multiple dimensions of the employee experience, all integrated with SAP SuccessFactors and SAP S/4HANA, all leveraging SAP Business AI where it adds value. Here is how that portfolio is taking shape:

Recognition and Rewards. Beyond SAP Appreciate, organizations are using recognition platforms integrated with SAP to connect appreciation to business outcomes. Recognition can align with SAP S/4HANA project structures, cost centers, and engagement codes, so leaders can see how appreciation flows alongside actual work. AI capabilities help employees craft meaningful recognition messages and help administrators detect patterns such as recognition equity gaps or program health trends.

Total Rewards Transparency. Employees often do not see the full value of what they receive from their employer. Total Rewards solutions consolidate salary, bonuses, benefits, equity, and perks into a single, personalized view inside SAP SuccessFactors. AI-powered communication tools help HR teams explain compensation changes clearly, and conversational interfaces let employees ask natural questions like "What's my annual bonus projection?" and receive plain-language answers. Solutions like Semos Cloud's Total Rewards Hub have achieved SAP Spotlight+ certification, reflecting deep alignment with SAP's platform direction.

Employee Communications. Reaching every employee, including deskless workers without corporate email, is a persistent challenge. Communications solutions integrated with SAP Work Zone and SAP SuccessFactors use live HRIS data to target messages by role, location, or lifecycle stage. AI helps generate surveys, summarize feedback, and identify themes that require attention.

Talent Development and Feedback. Managers often struggle to give timely, constructive feedback. AI-powered tools can help managers craft feedback that is specific, balanced, and aligned with company frameworks. Bias detection and language coaching features help ensure that feedback is fair and actionable.

Manager Support. Managers sit at the center of most People & Culture outcomes, but they work across fragmented systems. AI scenarios built on SAP data can surface timely insights: a high performer whose growth has stalled, a team that has not received recognition in months, a sensitive HR situation that needs policy-aligned guidance. These scenarios support managers in the flow of their work rather than adding another dashboard to check.

This breadth matters. People & Culture Intelligence is not a single application. It is a connected set of capabilities that help organizations understand and act on signals across recognition, rewards, communication, development, and leadership.

What This Looks Like in Large Enterprises

The same pattern appears in large customer environments.

A major global professional services firm, with hundreds of thousands of professionals across key entities, wanted to modernize how it recognizes and supports its people. They needed recognition and well-being programs that could reflect the way work actually happens: project-based, client-facing, and closely tied to SAP S/4HANA engagement structures.

Standard tools struggled with this. They treated recognition as a separate application, with limited understanding of project codes, cost centers, or the complex hierarchies inside SAP S/4HANA.

Working with SAP and Semos Cloud, the organization implemented a unified recognition and well-being layer connected directly to SAP S/4HANA. Local, country-level solutions were consolidated into a global program, while still respecting local cultures and regulations.

For HR and People & Culture teams, this created a single view of recognition and well-being across key entities. For managers, it meant that recognitions and well-being signals could be aligned with real projects and teams rather than existing in isolation.

This is one example of how SAP's platform and partner solutions create the foundation for People and Culture Intelligence: cultural and well-being signals integrated with business structures, not separated from them.

How SAP and Its Partners Are Moving Forward

For partners building AI solutions in the SAP ecosystem, the foundations for People and Culture Intelligence already exist. The next step is not just to embed models, but to operationalize agents that can act on top of SAP data and processes. 

SAP Business AI and the SAP BTP Generative AI Hub provide the core model and orchestration capabilities. SAP AI Foundation services offer the governance and lifecycle management needed for sensitive People & Culture use cases. The AI Build Acceleration Package gives partners access to expert guidance, reference architectures, and co-marketing opportunities as they bring these agentic solutions to market with lower risk. 

In this context, SAP‚Äôs ecosystem plays a critical role. SAP provides the trusted platform, data foundation, and guardrails, while partners bring domain-specific intelligence for People & Culture. By combining these strengths, the ecosystem can deliver agent-based HR experiences that do more than surface insights ‚Äì they can help trigger and track real actions across engagement, recognition, performance, and rewards. 

Partners like Semos Cloud are using this stack to design manager agents that work on top of SAP SuccessFactors. These agents apply People and Culture Intelligence to surface timely nudges, recommended actions, and concise insight summaries so managers know who to recognize, when to give feedback, and how to support their teams, while keeping data, controls, and processes anchored in SAP. 

‚ÄúAgentic AI will fundamentally change how managers and HR teams interact with People & Culture data. Rather than navigating dashboards and reports, leaders will increasingly rely on intelligent agents that understand business context, surface insights at the right moment, and help trigger meaningful actions. Within SAP SuccessFactors and SAP S/4HANA, these agents are becoming a natural way to translate People & Culture data into trusted, enterprise-ready outcomes‚Äîenabled by SAP‚Äôs platform and brought to life through its partner ecosystem.‚Äù

Stefan Haas ‚Äì SVP, Head of Technology Alliances, Platform and Incubation Partnerships at SAP

For HR and People & Culture leaders already running SAP SuccessFactors or SAP S/4HANA, many of the building blocks are in place. The strategic question is which agent-powered use cases to prioritize first, and how to introduce AI in ways that feel practical, trusted, and directly helpful to managers and employees.  

Conclusion

AI in People & Culture is not about adding features. It is about turning data into intelligence that managers and employees can actually use in the moments when it matters.

SAP Business AI provides a governed, context-rich foundation for that intelligence. The SAP partner ecosystem, including partners like Semos Cloud, turns that foundation into concrete programs, products, and workflows inside the SAP landscape.

For organizations running on SAP, the platform is ready and the partner ecosystem is active. The practical question is which People and Culture Intelligence use cases you want to explore first.

 

For Partners: Learn more about the AI Build Acceleration Package and explore how to build AI solutions on SAP Business AI.

For HR and People & Culture Leaders: Visit SAP Business AI and explore partner solutions such as Semos Cloud on SAP Store to see how People and Culture Intelligence can work within your SAP environment.

 

This article was co-authored by Semos Cloud and SAP. Semos Cloud is an SAP Spotlight+ partner and the technology behind SAP Appreciate, SAP's global recognition and rewards program.
